title: Problem Statement
content: Erdős Problem #961 asks about smooth numbers in consecutive intervals. A k-smooth number has all prime factors ≤ k. The question: how many consecutive integers > k can all be k-smooth? The function f(k) measures this maximum run length.

title: Smooth Numbers
content: A positive integer n is k-smooth if every prime factor of n is at most k. For example, 12 = 2²·3 is 3-smooth (factors 2,3 ≤ 3), while 30 = 2·3·5 is 5-smooth but not 4-smooth (factor 5 > 4). Smooth numbers are central to factoring algorithms.

title: Connection to Mathlib
content: We prove our definition of k-smooth is equivalent to membership in Mathlib's Nat.smoothNumbers (k+1). The offset by 1 is because smoothNumbers uses a strict bound: n ∈ smoothNumbers(k+1) means all prime factors are < k+1, i.e., ≤ k.

title: HasLargePrimeFactor Property
content: The key property: for a given k and n, every interval of n consecutive integers starting above k contains at least one number with a prime factor > k (not k-smooth). This is what f(k) minimizes.

title: Sylvester-Schur Theorem
content: The classical Sylvester-Schur theorem (1934): among any k consecutive integers greater than k, at least one has a prime factor > k. This establishes that f(k) ≤ k. Stated as axiom since the proof requires prime distribution analysis.

title: Definition of f(k)
content: f(k) is defined as the minimal n such that any n consecutive integers > k contain a non-k-smooth number. This uses Nat.find to extract the minimum from the existence proof provided by Sylvester-Schur.

title: Sylvester-Schur Bound
content: From the Sylvester-Schur theorem, we immediately get f(k) ≤ k. This is the 'trivial' bound: any k consecutive integers above k contain a non-smooth number. The proof is just applying minimality of f.

title: Erdős Bound (1955)
content: Erdős proved f(k) < 3k/log(k) for sufficiently large k. This shows f(k) grows sublinearly - slower than k. The proof uses properties of prime distribution and is stated as an axiom since it requires analytic number theory.

title: Jutila-Ramachandra-Shorey Bound
content: The strongest known upper bound: f(k) ≪ (log log log k / log log k) · (k/log k). Proved independently by Jutila (1974) and Ramachandra-Shorey (1973) using sieve methods. This is much stronger than Erdős's bound.

title: Polylogarithmic Conjecture
content: The main open conjecture: f(k) ≪ (log k)^C for some constant C. This predicts polylogarithmic growth, vastly smaller than the known O(k/polylog) bounds. The gap is enormous - roughly k vs log(k).

title: Small Examples
content: For k=2, 2-smooth numbers are powers of 2: 1,2,4,8,16... The gaps grow exponentially, so f(2) is small. For k=3, 3-smooth numbers are 2^a·3^b: 1,2,3,4,6,8,9,12... Again, gaps force f(3) ≤ 3 by Sylvester-Schur.

title: Connection to Problem #683
content: Problem #683 asks about gaps between smooth numbers directly. If g(k) is the largest gap between consecutive k-smooth numbers, then f(k) ≤ g(k) + 1. The two problems are 'essentially equivalent' - progress on either helps the other.
